comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06]

More correctly 'Locomotive 2029, a member of the Z20 class (former E-100 class)".

After the 1924 classification  the first two numerals depicted the class (ie 20) and the last two the number of the locomotive in the class (ie the 29th). The 'Z' was reserved for locomotives which preceded the system's instigation (ie 2029 was a member of the former  E or 100 class which were built before 1924 and this class was unlikely to be repeated)

The 1924 system was the third classification system used by the NSW railways for their locomotive stock. The first simply used the number of the first loco in the class - ie No 1 loco belonged to the 1-class; the second used a letter (ie Locos 60, 61, 62, 63, 64 and 65) formerly the 60-class became the O class, these were introduced in 1874 .For ease (?) the first two systems are sometimes combined so as to read the "O-60  class" or in the case above the "E-100" class.

This really gets confusing however as after the Second World War the NSWGR introduced another class called the "AD60" which was an articulated behemoth of a locomotive.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: So where was this photo taken ?   I am supposing it is an "Anzac Day"  tour   and not a tour of some unknown "Anzac Branch"

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/35179849@N08] Mitch, this is very good point ...my assumption was the line for Liverpool servicing the Anzac Rifle range. This website will tell you a little about it. www.nswrail.net/lines/show.php?name=NSW:holsworthy

comment.author: 53057445@N08
comment._content: E10 class actually, although 2029 was a later NSWGR built version about 1911 grouped together with the earlier class members, the first being loco E10 built new as a tank engine in 1891 as opposed to the later  A93/Z19 tender engine rebuilds from 1877-era engines.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: I think this photo is taken where the train is heading north under Newbridge Road.   It looks surprisingly similar today
